content.title: NSTEMI Management
content.summary: Risk stratification and evidence-based management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction
key_points: NSTEMI = elevated troponin + ischemic symptoms/ECG changes without ST elevation
Risk stratify using TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores
High-risk features warrant early invasive strategy (<24 hours)
Dual antiplatelet therapy + anticoagulation for all
Timing of angiography based on risk category

statement.text: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) management involves immediate antithrombotic therapy (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitor, anticoagulation), risk stratification to determine invasive strategy timing, and revascularization when appropriate. Very high-risk patients require immediate angiography (<2 hours); high-risk patients need early invasive strategy (<24 hours); intermediate-risk can have delayed invasive or ischemia-guided approach.
statement.formal: NSTEMI Management = Antithrombotic therapy + Risk stratification → [Very high risk: <2h angio | High risk: <24h angio | Intermediate: <72h or ischemia-guided]

explanation.intuition: NSTEMI typically involves subtotal or intermittent coronary occlusion - the artery is partially blocked, unlike STEMI where it's completely blocked. This means there's more time for decision-making, but the patient is still at significant risk. Risk stratification helps determine who benefits most from early intervention.
explanation.key_insight: The key difference from STEMI is timing: NSTEMI allows hours to days for catheterization decisions based on risk. However, very high-risk features (ongoing ischemia, hemodynamic instability, arrhythmias) mandate immediate intervention just like STEMI.
explanation.technical_details: GRACE score best predicts mortality and is recommended for risk stratification. TIMI score is simpler but less accurate. Invasive strategy means coronary angiography with intent to revascularize; ischemia-guided means medical management with angiography only if recurrent ischemia or positive stress test.

definitions_glossary.NSTEMI: Myocardial infarction with elevated troponin but without ST-segment elevation on ECG
definitions_glossary.unstable_angina: ACS with ischemic symptoms but without troponin elevation - now rare with high-sensitivity troponin
definitions_glossary.TIMI_risk_score: 7-point score predicting 14-day mortality/ischemic events in NSTE-ACS
definitions_glossary.GRACE_score: Registry-based score predicting in-hospital and 6-month mortality in ACS
definitions_glossary.HEART_score: 5-category score for chest pain risk stratification in emergency department
definitions_glossary.invasive_strategy: Routine coronary angiography with intent to revascularize regardless of stress testing
definitions_glossary.ischemia_guided_strategy: Medical management with angiography only for recurrent ischemia or positive stress test
definitions_glossary.dual_antiplatelet_therapy: Aspirin plus P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel)
definitions_glossary.complete_revascularization: Treatment of all significant coronary stenoses, not just culprit lesion
definitions_glossary.culprit_lesion: The specific coronary stenosis responsible for the acute event
definitions_glossary.refractory_ischemia: Persistent or recurrent chest pain despite optimal medical therapy
definitions_glossary.dynamic_ECG_changes: New or changing ST-T abnormalities during chest pain episodes

pathophysiology.mechanism: Partial or intermittent coronary occlusion, often due to plaque rupture with non-occlusive thrombus. Unlike STEMI, some antegrade flow is preserved, preventing transmural ischemia. However, the unstable plaque can progress to complete occlusion at any time.
pathophysiology.spectrum: NSTE-ACS represents a spectrum from unstable angina (no biomarker elevation) to NSTEMI (troponin positive). With high-sensitivity troponin, most patients previously classified as unstable angina are now reclassified as NSTEMI.

diagnostic_criteria.definition: Rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin with at least one value above 99th percentile, PLUS clinical features of myocardial ischemia, WITHOUT persistent ST-segment elevation
ECG_findings: May have normal ECG (does not exclude NSTEMI)

very_high_risk_features: Recurrent or ongoing chest pain refractory to medical therapy
Life-threatening arrhythmias (VT, VF, complete heart block)
Acute heart failure clearly related to NSTE-ACS
high_risk_features: Prior PCI within 6 months or prior CABG

TIMI_risk_score.scoring: 1 point each; 0-2 low, 3-4 intermediate, 5-7 high risk

immediate_management: P2Y12 inhibitor: ticagrelor 180mg preferred, or clopidogrel 600mg

invasive_strategy_timing.immediate_less_than_2_hours: Very high-risk features (hemodynamic instability, ongoing ischemia, arrhythmias)
invasive_strategy_timing.early_less_than_24_hours: High-risk features (GRACE >140, troponin positive, dynamic ECG changes)
invasive_strategy_timing.selective_ischemia_guided: Low-risk patients without recurrent symptoms or positive stress test

antiplatelet_agents.ticagrelor: 180mg load, then 90mg BID × 12 months; preferred over clopidogrel
antiplatelet_agents.clopidogrel: 600mg load, then 75mg daily × 12 months; if ticagrelor contraindicated
antiplatelet_agents.prasugrel: 60mg load, then 10mg daily; use only after coronary anatomy known; avoid if prior stroke/TIA

anticoagulation_options.UFH: Weight-based bolus + infusion; for PCI-bound patients
anticoagulation_options.enoxaparin: 1mg/kg SC q12h; if renal function adequate
anticoagulation_options.fondaparinux: 2.5mg SC daily; if conservative strategy planned (add UFH if PCI)

definition.@value: Evidence-based approach to managing non-ST elevation myocardial infarction including antithrombotic therapy, risk stratification, and determination of invasive versus conservative strategy

skos.scopeNote: Based on 2014 AHA/ACC NSTE-ACS Guidelines and 2021 ESC Guidelines
skos.example: 68-year-old diabetic female with troponin 0.85 ng/mL, ST depression V4-V6, GRACE score 152 - high-risk NSTEMI requiring early invasive strategy within 24 hours

medicalCode.description: Acute non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (disorder)

learning_objectives: Apply GRACE and TIMI risk scores to NSTEMI patients
Identify very high-risk features requiring immediate intervention
Select appropriate antiplatelet and anticoagulation regimens
Determine optimal timing of invasive strategy
Understand invasive vs ischemia-guided approach evidence
clinical_pearls: GRACE score predicts mortality better than TIMI for catheterization timing decisions
Ticagrelor preferred over clopidogrel for better outcomes (PLATO trial)
Prasugrel only after anatomy known - higher bleeding, contraindicated if prior stroke
Very high-risk features (shock, ongoing ischemia, VT/VF) = immediate cath like STEMI
Fondaparinux has less bleeding but needs UFH supplement at PCI time

board_yield.usmle_step2: Very High - risk stratification, treatment algorithm
board_yield.usmle_step3: High - antiplatelet selection, timing of intervention

skos:related.skos:note: Troponin defines NSTEMI vs unstable angina

sources.source: Amsterdam EA, et al. 2014 AHA/ACC Guideline for NSTE-ACS. Circulation 2014;130:e344-e426
sources.relevance: Primary US guideline for NSTE-ACS management

sources.source: Collet JP, et al. 2020 ESC Guidelines for NSTE-ACS. Eur Heart J 2021;42:1289-1367
